Award.AwardTitle: ADVANCE CCNY: Blueprint for Increased Representation and Advancement of Women in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create a blueprint to foster an equitable and supportive environment for all faculty members, especially women at City College (CCNY) in the City University of New York system. City College is the flagship science and engineering school in the system and a minority-serving institution. Change at CCNY is likely to impact the other colleges and lead to advancing women in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields throughout the system. CCNY will conduct a self-assessment of faculty perceptions, institutional policies and practices, and of the representation and advancement of women in STEM as a means towards developing the blueprint. Advancing women and minority faculty at CCNY will provide visible role models for more than half of the student population that is female, many of whom are from minority or disadvantaged backgrounds.

As City College moves into its next phase in transforming itself into a research-intensive university, it faces the challenge of remaining true to its mission of access and inclusive excellence, while upgrading its research profile and reputation. The goals of this proposal are to identify the cultural and environmental factors that promote or hinder the advancement of STEM women at City College. This information will be used to implement new policies to ensure that advancement is gender neutral and to provide a blueprint for effective career advancement of women. The specific objectives of the project are as follows: (a) to locate and identify obstacles to the representation and advancement of women STEM faculty; (b) to determine perceptual differences among faculty and administrators of different genders, races/ethnicities, ranks and disciplines; (c) to better understand cultural and environmental influences on these obstacles and perceptual differences; (d) to effect institutional transformation through targeted initiatives to remove barriers and remedy current inequities. A mixed methods approach will be used to obtain information from faculty that will be used alongside the policy review to develop the blueprint for institutional transformation. The data collection portion will be used to create a systematic data set that may be used in the future to monitor change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the of the IT Catalyst project was to create a blueprint for meaningful institutional transformation at CCNY that will foster an equitable and supportive professional environment for all faculty, with a particular emphasis on women.

The baseline data collected on tenure, promotion, and resource allocation provides a foundation for comparing the representation and advancement of women STEM and social and behavioral science (SBS) faculty to other CUNY senior colleges as well as to national institutions. The findings raised significant questions about the gender disparity in hiring; the gender disparity in giving raises outside required union steps; and a gender disparity in resource allocation (i.e., space, size of space, etc.). The ongoing collection and analysis of these data provides a basis for developing strategies to increase the representation and advancement of women STEM faculty.

The findings from the qualitative study of faculty and the IT Catalyst survey of STEM and SBS deans and chairs highlights significant obstacles that impact the representation and advancement of STEM and SBS female faculty at CCNY. The consistent themes that emerged from the interviews were that female faculty experienced similar obstacles in their career advancement including sabotaged projects, denial of tenure and/or promotion, lack of mentoring opportunities, and a sense of isolation-based on demographic make-up and/or research emphasis.  Respondents overlapped in how they have overcome career path obstacles including creating their own professional networks, with members of their networks often being outside of CCNY.

The survey results revealed several areas of disconnect between CUNY and CCNY formal policies and practices and/or their intent so far as influencing the representation of women in STEM and SBS fields. In particular, the findings highlight:

  • Mentoring of faculty for career advancement is not universal and approaches to mentoring are not uniform. Additionally, there is little mentoring of tenured Associate Professors.
  • Practices of granting additional released time for new faculty (beyond contract provisions) vary considerably among departments.
  • Many units claim to protect vulnerable faculty from excessive service load but generally no workload reduction for substantial service burden is given.
  • Work/life balance is often informal accommodations for faculty and encouragement of faculty to take advantage of family, parental and academic leave policies are lacking in many units.
  • Efforts to promote inclusion and community are generally haphazard and vary considerably in intensity among academic units. Observations were made regarding internal and external barriers to recruiting a diverse STEM and SBS faculty, such as a lack of a focus on diverse recruiting in some departments, inadequate starting packages and salaries, and external competition for a relatively small candidate pool.
  • There are many negative observations about quality of life and infrastructure for research, teaching, and service. Infrastructure issues often compromise the ability of junior faculty to be productive in research.

Using the findings from institutional data, faculty interviews, and survey results, the project team engaged senior administrators in the development of a blueprint to transform the institution and measure success.

The blueprint is designed to foster an equitable and supportive professional environment for all faculty with a particular emphasis on STEM women faculty. The model included: (1) The Research Advancement and Leadership Initiative; (2) The Collective of Faculty for Change Initiative; and (3) The Initiative on Institutional Culture. Specific components of the blueprint includes:

  • Designing a structured, institutional approach to recruiting and mentoring STEM female faculty;
  • Increasing the retention of women STEM faculty and supporting their advancement in research, promotion, and appointment to leadership positions;
  • Increasing the productivity, visibility, and recognition of women STEM faculty in research;
  • Enhancing CCNY’s infrastructure, environment, and faculty support systems to promote an inclusive and equitable research portfolio across the institution;
  • Reviewing, modifying, and instituting policies, procedures and practices to sustain women STEM faculty;
  • Developing The Center for Excellence in Research;
  • Sustaining and regularly updating the faculty data (i.e., distribution of faculty by gender, rank, department, etc.)
  • Disseminating findings across CUNY.
